title: 115_hr1753
content: The Act may be cited as the "Opportunities for Fairness in Farming Act of 2017". Congress finds that generic checkoff programs are intended to increase demand for agricultural commodities and benefit all producers. However, these programs have been found to use funds to influence policy, leading to conflicts of interest and harming many producers. Strict separation between checkoff boards and policy entities is necessary to prevent misuse of funds. Conflicts of interest in checkoff programs allow special interests to benefit some producers at the expense of others. Prohibiting such conflicts is necessary for lawful operation. Checkoff programs should promote commodities without damaging others or engaging in anticompetitive behavior. Lack of transparency enables abuses, so requiring transparency in fund expenditure is crucial to prevent and uncover misconduct. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "Board" as an entity for carrying out checkoff programs, and "checkoff program" as a promotion and research program for agricultural commodities without specific producers or brands mentioned. It includes programs like the Cotton Research and Promotion Act, Potato Research and Promotion Act, Egg Research and Consumer Information Act, Beef Research and Information Act, Wheat and Wheat Foods Research and Nutrition Education Act, and Floral Research and Consumer Information Act. The curr_chunk lists various agricultural acts such as the Honey Research Act and the Mushroom Promotion Act. The curr_chunk lists agricultural acts including the Lime Research Act, Soybean Promotion Act, Fluid Milk Promotion Act, Fresh Cut Flowers Act, Sheep Promotion Act, Federal Agriculture Improvement Act, Commodity Promotion Act, Canola and Rapeseed Act, and National Kiwifruit Act. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "conflict of interest" and "Secretary" under various agricultural acts such as the Canola and Rapeseed Research Act and the Hass Avocado Promotion Act. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENTS OF CHECKOFF PROGRAMS. Prohibitions include not entering contracts with parties influencing government policies related to agriculture, avoiding conflicts of interest, and prohibiting anticompetitive or deceptive activities. Boards must obtain approval from the Secretary to enter into contracts. The Board may enter contracts for promotion, research, or other activities with approval from the Secretary. Contracts must include accurate record-keeping of funds and goods/services provided. Budgets and disbursements approved by the Secretary must be published for public inspection. The Board must publish all budgets and disbursements approved by the Secretary for public inspection, including the amount, purpose, recipient, and other parties involved. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture must conduct periodic audits every 5 years. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture conducts audits every 5 years to ensure compliance of each checkoff program with the regulations. The audit includes a review of records submitted to the Board, and a report is submitted to Congress upon completion. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct an audit every 3-5 years to assess compliance of each checkoff program with regulations. The audit report will be submitted to Congress and the appropriate committees. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct audits every 3-5 years to ensure compliance of checkoff programs. The audit report will include recommendations to improve program integrity and federal legislation. The Inspector General reports will be considered in preparing these recommendations. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
